# Pathogenesis

*   Microorganisms may reach the lungs via the airways (Aspiration / Inhalation), bloodstream, or lymphatics or Direct spread
    *   from Adj. organs.
*   First step in many infections is colonization of the upper airway and reach lung by micro aspiration from the oropharynx.

# PATHOLOGICAL TYPES



## Lobar pneumonia
Diffuse consolidation involving the entire lobe of the lung.
Four stages of lobar pneumonia have been described.
MC pattern in CAP



## Bronchopneumonia
Patchy neutrophilic inflammation in is centered in bronchi and bronchioles, with centrifugal spread to the adjacent alveoli may be due to aspiration of oropharyngeal contents.
MC Noscomial pneumonia pattern



## Interstitial pneumonia
Inflammation involving the interstitium is characterized by infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages.
The alveoli do not contain a significant exudate.
Ex Viral pneumonia

In idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and asbestosis, fine crackles can be discerned before radiologic abnormalities are detected and are thus considered to be an early sign of pulmonary impairment.24,25 Although the presence of Velcro rales as heard on auscultation has not been formally accepted as diagnostic of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, auscultation is considered to be the only realistic means of detection early in the course of the disease.25 In asbestosis, the use of computerized detection of crackles has appeared to be as accurate as CT in locating disease that is not radiologically apparent.25 In a study of 386 workers exposed to asbestos,26 crackle detection by means of auscultation performed by a trained physician correctly identified all the cases of asbestosis, suggesting that auscultation may have a role to play as a noninvasive method of screening in these populations.

MDR organisms - CAP

*   Staphylococcus
*   Risk factors : PES score / DRIP (Drug resistance in Pneumonia score)

PES Score
*   (one point each) : age 40-65 years and male sex
*   (two points each) : Age >65 years, Previous antibiotic use, Chronic respiratory disorder, Impaired consciousness
*   (three points) : Chronic renal failure

DRIP score
*   (two points each) : previous antibiotic use, residence in a long-term care facility, tube feeding and prior infection by a drug-resistant pathogen (within the past year)
*   (one point each): hospitalization within the previous 60 days, chronic pulmonary disease, poor functional status, gastric acid suppression, wound care and MRSA colonization (within the past year).

## Aspiration pneumonia

*   **Chemical injury pneumonitis (Mendelson syndrome)** - posterior segment of the right upper lobe and superior segment of the right lower lobe
*   High concentrations of amylase or pepsinogen in BAL fluid
*   Anaerobic infection - 1 to 2 weeks after aspiration
*   Segmental opacification with multiple small areas of necrosis that evolve into cavities (<2 cm in diameter), usually without air-fluid levels
*   Organisms: *E. exsiccans*, *Prevotella*, *Porphyromonas*, *Peptostreptococcus*, microaerophilic *Streptococcus* species, *Veillonella* species. (Handwritten additions: *Bacteroides*, *Prevotella*, *Peptostreptococcus*, *F. nucleatum*)



## Chronic pneumonias

*   Persistence of symptoms for at least **6 weeks**
*   **Actinomyces**
*   Chest wall lesions and draining sinuses
*   Direct extension of a cavity or mass through an interlobar fissure
*   Diagnosis: **sulfur granules** containing a mass of mycelial elements in a protein and polysaccharide matrix, and granulomatous-like reactions



## Pulmonary Anthrax

*   Gram-positive spore-forming
*   Contaminated animal hides, wool, meat, bones or drug injection
*   Types: Cutaneous, Gastrointestinal, Injectional, Inhalational
*   **Inhalational (wool-sorter's disease)** - most severe
*   Incubation: 4 days
*   Characteristics: Diffuse edema of the neck and anterior chest
*   Radiology: widened mediastinum and bilateral pleural effusions
*   Clinical triad: Mediastinal widening, confusion, and a raised hematocrit



## Pulmonary Anthrax - Treatment

*   Diagnosis: Culture - "**boxcar**" chains, IHC, PCR
*   Treatment
*   Initial Phase: Ciprofloxacin, doxycycline + clindamycin 600 mg, penicillin G, meropenem, rifampin. **Raxibacumab** - Monoclonal antibody
*   Continuation phase: ciprofloxacin or doxycycline
*   About 60 days - eliminate spores

## VIRAL PNEUMONIA

*   Adenovirus - non enveloped DNA virus - Cidofovir, Brincidofovir (Oral)
*   Corona virus - RNA virus - DAD
    *   2003 - SARS - C
    *   2012 - MERS Co V - Camels
    *   2019 - SARS Co V2 - ? Bats
*   Hanta Virus - Rodent borne : Zoonotic
    *   Hanta Pulmonary Disease / Haemorrhagic disease with renal syndrome
    *   Triad : thrombocytopenia, left shift with circulating myeloblasts, and circulating immunoblasts



## VIRAL PNEUMONIA

*   Herpes Simplex virus : DNA virus
*   HSV-1 Pneumonia - Immunocompromised
*   Herpetic laryngotracheitis or herpetic lesions of other mucocutaneous sites
*   HSV DNA by PCR from LRT specimens (e.g., BAL) or lung biopsy
*   Treatment : oral valacyclovir or intravenous acyclovir
*   Varicella Zoster :Miliary opacities + miliary calcified



## Non resolving pneumonia

*   Progressive pneumonia - clinical deterioration - respiratory failure or septic shock
*   Nonresponding pneumonia - clinical improvement is not achieved (persistence of fever and clinical symptoms
    *   - 72 hours of antibiotic treatment
    *   - reduction of PCT levels after 3 to 4 days of treatment correlates with clinical response



## Nocardiosis

*   Impaired cell-mediated immunity, bronchiectasis and COPD
*   NS and skin - most common extrapulmonary sites
*   Modified Kinyoun acid-fast Stain
*   TMP-SMX, minocycline, amikacin, ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, imipenem, tigecycline, fluoroquinolones, and linezolid
*   Rhodococcus
*   Weakly acid-fast
*   Smaller than mycobacteria



## VIRAL PNEUMONIA

*   CMV - DNA - Miliary pattern / Interstitial pattern
*   Most common infectious cause of interstitial pneumonia among transplant recipients
*   CMV pneumonia : 30 and 90 days post transplant
*   Late-onset CMV syndromes > 180 days
*   Diagnosis : PCR in serum or BAL Fluid, histologic evidence of viral inclusions on biopsy
*   Treatment : IV Ganciclovir -> oral valganciclovir, CMV immune globulin
*   Alternative : Foscarnet, cidofovir
*   @gmail.com
*   Prophylaxis : Letermovir : CMV terminase complex inhibitor

# Assessment of severity of Pneumonia

(CRB65)

*   **C** Confusion
*   **U** Urea > 40 mg/L (or) > 7 mmol/L
    *   *BUN: >20 mg%*
*   **R** Respiratory rate > 30/min
*   **B** Blood pressure: SBP < 90 mmHg (or) DBP < 60 mmHg
*   **65** Age > 65 years

*   0, 1 points $\Rightarrow$ OPRx (Outpatient treatment)
*   2 points $\Rightarrow$ WARD Rx (Ward admission)
*   $\ge 3$ points $\Rightarrow$ IPRx (Inpatient treatment / ICU)

# CRB65

*Note: Used where Blood Investigations (Ix) not possible*

**Criteria (each scores 1 point):**

*   U: Urea > 40 mg/l (or) > 7 mmol/l
*   R: Respiratory rate > 30/min
*   B: SBP < 90 (or) DBP < 60
*   65: Age > 65

**Scoring and Management:**

*   **0-1 point(s):** OPRx (Outpatient treatment)
*   **2 points:** WARD Rx (Ward admission/treatment)
    *   *Note:* Couple get admitted in ward
*   **3-5 points:** Consider as severe pneumonia, may require ICU

*For 2-5 points: IPRx (Inpatient treatment)*

# TABLE 128-5 Criteria for Severe Community-acquired Pneumonia

## Minor criteria$^a$
*   Respiratory rate $\ge 30$ breaths/min$^b$
*   PaO$_2$/FiO$_2 \le 250^b$
*   Multilobar infiltrates
*   Confusion/disorientation
*   Uremia (BUN $\ge 20$ mg/dL)
*   Leukopenia (WBC count $<100,000$ cells/mm$^3$)$^c$
*   Hypothermia (core temperature $<36^\circ$C)
*   Hypotension requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation
*(Handwritten annotation: SCAP)*

## Major criteria
*   Invasive mechanical ventilation
*   Septic shock with need for vasopressors
*(Handwritten annotation: IRVS [above] - intubation, vasopressor use)*

# DISCHARGE

If Pt start accepting orally, are afebrile and are haemodynamically stable for a period of at least 48 hours.
Out-patients should be treated for five days and in-patients for seven days

OP Rx: 5d
IP Rx: 7d

---

<!-- Page 68 -->



# FOLLOW UP

*   Antibiotic may be changed if the response is not satisfactory even after 48 to 72 hours of treatment initiation
*   Radiological clearance is delayed compared to clinical resolution. Routine follow up chest x ray is not required if there is satisfactory clinical response
*   In case of smokers above 40 years or if there are any unusual features or if there is slow resolution, then it is better to get follow up chest x ray after 6 weeks or later
*   Hospitalized Patients may be followed up 1 week after discharge. A further follow up later is required in most of the patients to assess for complete resolution of pneumonia
    *   (Handwritten note: 1 month (4-6 wks))

# Severe CAP / sCAP

*   If available, we suggest sending a **lower respiratory tract sample** (either sputum or endotracheal aspirates) for *multiplex PCR testing* (virus and/or bacterial detection) whenever *non-standard sCAP antibiotics* are prescribed or considered
*   **sCAP** + **acute hypoxaemic respiratory failure not needing immediate intubation** â†’ *high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO)* > **standard oxygen**
*   Addition of **macrolides** (R: immunomodulatory property extra), not **fluoroquinolones**, to *beta-lactams as empirical antibiotic* therapy in *hospitalised patients with sCAP*

---

<!-- Page 70 -->

Biomarkers in pneumonia



# ROLE OF PROCALCITONIN IN sCAP

We suggest the use of PCT to reduce the duration of antibiotic treatment in patients with sCAP. The recommendation of using PCT must be considered together with clinical assessment. PCT might not be useful when clinical stability is achieved, and duration of antibiotic therapy is between 5 and 7 days.

Procalcitonin is produced by the neuroendocrine cells of the lung and intestine.

released as an acute-phase reactant in response to inflammatory stimuli, especially those of bacterial origin (endotoxin) and inflammatory cytokines.

serum procalcitonin in response to Viral infections and noninfectious inflammatory stimuli such as autoimmune disease and chronic inflammatory processes are much less pronounced, rarely exceeding 0.5 ng/ml.

---

<!-- Page 71 -->



# Biomarkers in pneumonia



## Procalcitonin (PCT)
*   Diagnosis of bacterial versus nonbacterial infection
*   Need for antibiotic therapy
*   Prediction of severity of CAP (ICU admission/ triaging emergency room patients)
*   Prognosis of pneumonia patients
*   Duration of antibiotic treatment



## C-reactive protein (CRP)
*   Prediction of severity of CAP
*   Diagnosis of bacterial versus nonbacterial infection

Serum CRP is an acute phase protein synthesized exclusively in the liver. Its secretion is initiated 4 to 6 h after an insult (effect mediated by cytokines namely interleukin-6).



## Pro-adrenomedullin (Pro-ADM)
*   Severity of CAP

Mid-regional proadrenomedullin (MR-proADM) is a new biomarker of endothelial damage and its clinical use is increasing in sepsis and respiratory infections and recently in SARS-CoV-2 infection.



## B-natriuretic peptide (BNP)
*   Severity of CAP

Proinflammatory cytokines might increase plasma BNP from ventricles. A high BNP level ($\ge 200 \text{ pg/mL}$) at admission was a predictor of CAP-related death.



## Troponin I
*   Degree of hypoxemia: severity of illness

In response to infection, soluble TREM-1 (sTREM-1) is either secreted or shed. sTREM-1 levels can then be measured in body fluids.

proinflammatory cytokines might increase plasma BNP from ventricles. A high BNP level (â‰¥ 200 pg/mL) at admission was a predictor of CAP-related death.

In response to infection, soluble TREM-1 (sTREM-1) is either secreted or shed. sTREM-1 levels can then be measured in body fluids like BAL. BAL fluid sTREM-1 has been suggested as a biomarker to differentiate VAP positive from VAP negative patients.

<!-- Page 73 -->

ERS/ESICM/ESCMID/ALAT guidelines for the management of severe community-acquired pneumonia : 2023

We suggest the use of oseltamivir for patients with sCAP due to influenza confirmed by PCR. When PCR is not available to confirm influenza, we suggest the use of empirical oseltamivir during the influenza season.

In patients with sCAP, we suggest the use of corticosteroids if shock is present. Based on common exclusion criteria from clinical trials, this recommendation does not apply to patients with viral sCAP (influenza, SARS, and MERS), uncontrolled diabetes and corticos-teroid treatment for other reasons.

When corticosteroid therapy is considered, methylprednisolone (0.5 mg/kg-1 every 12 h for 5 days) is a reasonable option.

# VENTILATOR ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA

1.  **Aspiration & intubation procedure**

2.  **Biofilm formation**: Biofilm forms inside and outside the ET Tube

*   The presence of endotracheal tubes and antibiotic administration may promote pathogenic bacterial colonization in the airways, contributing to both lower microbiota diversity and the development of an intermediate (initial form) respiratory infection termed ventilator-associated tracheobronchitis (VAT) (before VAP).
*   Tracheitis is the presence of clinical signs of purulent tracheal discharge, fevers, respiratory distress, and the presence of bacteria and white blood cells in the tracheal aspirate without radiological signs of pneumonia.

## WHEN TO SUSPECT NOSOCOMIAL PNEUMONIA ?? [Simplest]

*   Any patient with new or progressive radiographic opacities and clinical signs or symptoms indicative of infection : fever, leukocytosis or leukopenia, purulent sputum, or worsening oxygenation.
*   These clinical findings are neither sensitive nor specific, and there is no gold standard for the diagnosis of HAP or VAP

*   Chest radiographic opacities (new, progressive or persistent infiltrate or cavitation)

    *   4. New onset of purulent sputum, or increased respiratory secretions,
    *   5. Worsening gas exchange
    *   6. New onset or worsening cough, or dyspnoea, or tachypnoea

VAP

\* ETA VS BAL VS PSB
5 4 3

*   The bacteriologic strategy uses **quantitative cultures** of the **LRT** via **endotracheal aspirate**, **protected specimen brush**, or **bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)**.
*   The thresholds differ depending on the method of respiratory sampling and are as follows:
*   $\ge 10^5$ colony-forming units (CFU)/mL for an endotracheal aspirate.
*   $\ge 10^4$ CFU/mL for a BAL.
*   and $\ge 10^3$ CFU/mL for a protected specimen brush.
*   Results of these procedures guide decisions such as when to initiate or stop antibiotics and the drug(s) to be used against the offending agent.
*   There are no **definitive data** to support the use of one sampling technique over another; however, **cellular analysis of BAL fluid** may provide an advantage, as a sample **containing <50% neutrophils produced excellent negative predictive value** in one study.

# RISK FACTORS FOR MDR PATHOGENS

*   Antibiotics in last 90 days
*   Been hospitalised for >5 days prior current HAP/VAP or >2 days in previous 90 days
*   Critical illness : Septic shock , ARDS prior VAP
*   Chronic lung disease : COPD, BXIS
*   Dialysis prior VAP
*   Evidence of high local antibiotic resistance
    *   Multiresistant GNB, such as P. aeruginosa,
    *   Extended-spectrum $\beta$-lactamase producing (ESBL) Enterobacteriaceae (Escherichia coli â€“ and Klebsiella pneumoniae
    *   carbapenemase-producing organisms,
    *   MRSA,

| Intravenous antimicrobials in previous 90 days                                |
| Chronic lung disease including COPD, cystic fibrosis, pulmonary fibrosis, or bronchiectasis |
| Residence in high-risk environment including LTAC or skilled nursing facility |
| Tracheostomy                                                                  |
| Septic shock at the time of VAP onset                                         |
| ARDS prior to VAP onset                                                       |
| Immunosuppressive therapy                                                     |
| Hospitalization for >2 days in the previous 90 days                           |
| Indwelling vascular or urinary catheter                                       |
| Home wound care                                                               |
| Current hospitalization for 5 d or greater                                    |
| High rates of local antibiotic resistance                                     |
| Acute renal replacement therapy prior to VAP onset                            |

## SUMMARY:


### Antibiotic principals

(01:00:00)

**CAP (Community Acquired Pneumonia)**
*   **$\ominus$ Comorb (No Comorbidity)**
    *   Macrolide | Blactam | Tetracycline
*   **$\oplus$ Comorb (With Comorbidity)**
    *   Amoxyclav
    *   Blactam + macrolide
    *   [Typical] + [Atypical]

**IP Rx (Inpatient Rx)**
*   **Pyramid of Antibiotics:**
    1.  Amoxyclav | Ceftriaxone
    2.  Piptaz | Cefoperazone
    3.  Meropenem
    4.  Colistin

*   **Branches from IP Rx:**
    *   **Non ICU**
        *   Blactam + mac $\rightarrow$ Azithro
        *   [Amoxyclav]
        *   $\checkmark$ Ceftriaxone
    *   **ICU**
        *   $\approx$ Blactam + mac
        *   $\rightarrow$ Piptaz
        *   $\rightarrow$ Cefoperazone sulbactam

**General Principle:**
*   Gram+ve > Gram-ve
    *   *Streptococci likely helpful*

---

**Special Conditions:**

*   \* If pseudomonas suspected: Antipseudomonal Blactam

**HAP|VAP (Hospital Acquired Pneumonia | Ventilator Associated Pneumonia)**
*   **Non MDR** $\approx$ Amoxyclav | Ceftriaxone (Like Non-ICU)
*   **MDR [Pseudomonas]** $\rightarrow$ Piptaz | Cefsulb (x) (Meropenem) + FQ (or) Aminoglycoside

*   \* ESBL producing $\Rightarrow$ Meropenem
*   \* Carbapenem resistant $\Rightarrow$ Colistin
    *   $\hookrightarrow$ Kill Acinetobacter

---

**MRSA:**
*   Vancomycin
*   Linezolid
*   Teicoplanin

## Continuous Removal of Subglottic Secretions

*   Use an ET tube with continuous suction through a dorsal lumen above the cuff to prevent drainage accumulation.
*   Avoiding nasal insertion of endotracheal and gastric tubes
*   maintaining the endotracheal tube cuff pressure above **20 cm H2O** to prevent leakage of bacteria around the cuff into the lower respiratory tract.

CDC Guideline for Prevention of Healthcare Associated Pneumonias
2004 ATS/IDSA Guidelines for VAP
2005



### Controversial

*   **Selective decontamination of the digestive tract (SDD)** to eradicate potentially pathogenic bacteria
    *   Using cefotaxime, trimethoprim or a fluoroquinolone, and topical administration of nonabsorbable antibiotics (usually an aminoglycoside, polymyxin B, and amphotericin) to the mouth and stomach, in order to eradicate potentially pathogenic bacteria and yeast that may cause infections

*   Avoid unnecessary PPIs, histamine2 [H2] blockers can increase **gastric pH** & gastric bacterial burden and increase the risk of VAP
*   Sucralfate may be given

# POST COVID FATIGUE

The decrease in physical and/or mental performance that results from changes in central, psychological, and/or peripheral factors due to the COVID-19 disease

MINIMISE ENERGY EXPENDITURE



## POST COVID FATIGUE

*   **Central factors**: neurotransmitter levels (e.g., dopamine and serotonin), intrinsic neuronal excitability, inflammation, demyelination (resulting in changes in axonal conduction velocity)
*   **Peripheral factors**: COVID-19 may directly impact skeletal muscle â†’ pain, skeletal muscle weakness, and injury occurrence
*   **Psychological factors**: Stress, anxiety, depression, and fear

# OUR EXPERIENCE - Anti fibrotics

*   **When do I start?**
    Resting hypoxemia beyond 2-3 weeks of covid illness with CT/CXR suggestive of fibrosis starting antifibrotics with pul rehabilitation
*   **How do I monitor for response?**
    Every month with 6min walk test and clinical response.
*   **When do I plan to stop Anti fibrotics?**
    Once their resting spo2 improves will plan to stop antifibrotics. Any antifibrotic drugs take at least 1-3 months to demonstrate an effect. This was the time period at which the FVC started to improve compared to placebo in the INBUILD, INPULSIS, and ASCEND trials
*   **Preferred Anti fibrotic at our centre?**
    Nintedanib

AND IN COVID ILD MOST IMPORTANT IS PT'S DETERMINATION AND PUL REHABILITATION

# STEROIDS

Ann Am Thorac Soc Vol 18, No 5, pp 773-779, May 2021
Internet address: www.atsjournals.org

Post-COVID lung fibrosis: The tsunami that will follow the earthquake
Zarir F Udwadia1, Parvaiz A Koul2, Luca Richeldi3

837 patients who survived hospitalization for SARS-CoV-2 infection at a single center in the United Kingdom, the authors found that 7% of patients had persistent interstitial changes on chest computed tomography (CT) 6 weeks after hospital discharge. The majority of these (35 out of 59, or 4% of the entire cohort) had an organizing pneumonia (OP)-like pattern, with bilateral subpleural ground-glass infiltrates in a mid- to lower-zone distribution, at times associated with subpleural and peribronchial linear dense consolidation, and traction bronchiectasis in some patients. These patients were offered treatment with corticosteroids (0.5 mg/kg prednisolone) with a taper over 3 weeks, on average. All 30 patients who received corticosteroid treatment reported subjective improvement in breathlessness and physical functioning and had objective improvements in lung function and chest imaging.

on moderately high doses of steroids through their illness [Figure 4]. Steroids should, in our opinion, be continued on discharge if the CT scan prior to discharge continues to show significant GGOs and the patient remains hypoxic. At this stage again, we would caution against the use of large doses of oral steroids as they could worsen hyperglycemia and contribute to proximal myopathy which in turn would retard the patients' mobility and rehabilitation. We recommend using no more than 20-30 mg of prednisolone at discharge and tapering it on follow-up depending on the patient's response.

athi MD FIP

# Influenza

*   Single-stranded enveloped RNA viruses
*   Commonest cause of viral pneumonia in immunocompetent adults. It is transmitted via respiratory secretion



## Types

*   Influenza A
    (Influenza virus types A&B cause most human illness and the flu season)
*   Influenza B



### Subtypes (for Influenza A)

*   A(H1N1)
*   A(H3N2)



### Lineages (for Influenza B)

*   B(Victoria)
*   B(Yamagata)

(Visual representation of Influenza virus with surface antigens)
*   H (Haemagglutinin)
*   N (Neuraminidase)

*   Haemagglutinin helps the virus invade a target cell.
*   Neuraminidase helps new virus particles break out of that cell.

*   Surface antigens (Proteins) haemagglutinin and neuraminidase determine influenza serotype.
*   Genetic mutations may result in antigenic shifts (major genetic rearrangements between strains, associated with pandemics of influenza A â€” 1918 (H1N1), 1957 (H2N2), & 2009 (H1N1))
    *   *Handwritten note:* Shift: H1N1
*   Antigenic drifts (more minor genetic variations associated with epidemics)
    *   -H3N2 subtype of influenza A virus in india
    *   *Handwritten note:* Drift: H3N2

# Ministry of Health & Family Welfare : Seasonal Influenza (2019)



## Cat A
Patients with **mild fever plus cough / sore throat + bodyache, headache, diarrhoea and vomiting**. **No need Oseltamivir and H1N1 testing.**



## Cat B (i)
Category-A PLUS + **high grade fever and severe sore throat**, â†’ home isolation and **Oseltamivir**;



## Cat B (ii)
**Category-A PLUS** individuals having one or more of the **high risk** conditions shall be treated with **Oseltamivir**. No tests for H1N1 is required for Category-B (i) and (ii).



## Cat C
of Category-A and B, + one or more of the following: **Breathlessness, chest pain, drowsiness, fall in blood pressure, sputum mixed with blood, bluish discolouration of nails**; (SOB / chest pain / shock / sputum mixed c blood / Cyanosis)
*   **Immediate hospitalization testing and treatment and send for testing.**

*   Cardiovascular diseases
*   Renal diseases
*   Hemoglobinopathies
*   HIV



### Abbreviations
DM, Diabetes mellitus; COPD, Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; HIV, Human immunodeficiency virus

# CYTOMEGALOVIRUS PNEUMONIA $\Rightarrow$ Pneumonia in I/C $\ominus$

*   Enveloped $\underline{\text{dsDNA}}$ virus
*   Pneumonia in the $\underline{\text{immunocompromised}}$
*   Infection in transplant recipients results from either transmission from a CMV $\underline{\text{positive donor}}$ (via the organ or a blood transfusion) or $\underline{\text{reactivation of latent}}$ CMV in a $\underline{\text{seropositive recipient}}$ as a result of $\underline{\text{immunosuppression}}$
*   Infection occurs most frequently during the $\underline{\text{first 4 months}}$ following organ or bone marrow transplantation, corresponding to the period of $\underline{\text{maximal t-cell}}$ suppression.
*   $\text{\textasteriskcentered}$ Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) increases the risk of CMV infection

# CMV Pathogenesis

*(Handwritten: Dr Bharath Kathi)*
*(Handwritten: - Dysregulated Immune Response)*

*   partly related to **viral replication** but is also thought to have an **immunopathologic basis**.

*   other is of **interstitial character**, with **alveolar-cell hyperplasia** (ACH\*), **interstitial edema**, lymphoid infiltration, and diffusely distributed cytomegalic cells.

*   CXR typically bilateral $\underline{\text{diffuse interstitial}}$ infiltrate, although $\underline{\text{lobar consolidation}}$ and localized haziness also described
*   CT Features include $\underline{\text{localized}}$ or $\underline{\text{diffuse}}$ $\underline{\text{ground-glass}}$ and $\underline{\text{nodular shadowing}}$ that may progress to airspace $\underline{\text{consolidation}}$
*   Dx: $\underline{\text{PCR in serum or BAL}}$, $\underline{\text{histologic evidence}}$ of $\underline{\text{viral inclusions on biopsy}}$
*   Rx: Reduce immunosuppression where possible.
    *   $\checkmark$ $\underline{\text{Ganciclovir 5 mg/kg IV bd for 2-4 weeks}}$ (1 month)

# RSV

RSV
â†³ ssRNA
â†³ Ribavirin

*   Single-stranded enveloped RNA virus; subtypes A and B. Subtype A (more severe disease)
*   Very common cause of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in children.
*   Role in adult respiratory disease is more significant than previously
*   Clinical features in adults are usually of URTI or tracheobronchitis, but this may progress to pneumonia, particularly in the setting of underlying cardiac or respiratory disease, malignancy, or immunosuppression;
*   outbreaks affecting adults in hospitals and nursing homes also occur.
*   Dx: nasopharyngeal secretions and BAI fluid are often diagnostic; detection of RSV antigen / PCR-based test / serology
*   Bacterial superinfection may be a frequent complication
*   Rx: supportive. Ribavirin and steroids in the treatment of severe disease in adults is unclear *R-R*
*   Reports of successful outcomes in bone marrow transplant recipients following treatment with ribavirin and immunoglobulin.

# Varicella pneumonia

*   Caused by varicella-zoster virus (an enveloped dsDNA virus)
*   Pneumonia occurs in a small proportion of adults with chickenpox or shingles but can be severe
*   Risk factors: smoking, increased number of skin spots (>100), pregnancy (third trimester), steroid treatment and immunocompromise â­
*   CF: H/O recent exposure to a contact infected with chickenpox or shingles with rash (erythematous macules progressing to papules and then vesicles) f/b Cough and breathlessness, pleuritic pain and haemoptysis may occur
*   CXR typically shows a diffuse small nodular infiltrate; hilar lymphadenopathy and pleural effusions may uncommonly occur. Nodules may subsequently calcify and persist (to look like TB nodules (may))
*   Diagnosis: H/O exposure, presence of rash, and CXR features. Cytological examination of smears from skin lesions, serology, or viral culture or PCR on BAL fluid may confirm the diagnosis
*   Rx: aciclovir 10-12.5mg/kg IV tds for 7-10 days
*   Consider early administration of varicella zoster immune globulin for immunocompromised and pregnant patients â­

# PNEUMONIA IN IMMUNOCOMPROMISED

Overall, there are six main types of immunosuppression:
1.  Iatrogenic (through steroidal and nonsteroidal agents);
2.  Neutropenia (usually through antineoplastic chemotherapy);
3.  Haematopoietic stem-cell transplantation (HSCT);
4.  Solid-organ transplantation;
5.  Uncontrolled HIV infection;
6.  Innate or acquired T- and B-cell deficiencies.

# Mucormycosis
$\rightarrow$ mucor
$\rightarrow$ Rhizopus
\* URT + LRT + CNS involvement

*   **Riskfactors** : MC : (DM) \*
*   **Pathology** : Similar to Aspergillus, mucormycosis is angioinvasive, resulting in thrombosis, infarction, and tissue necrosis, with risk for dissemination to other sites.
    tit ===
*   **Signs and symptoms**:
    1.  Facial pain, pain over sinuses, pain in teeth and gums
    2.  Decreased sensation over half of face.
    3.  Blackish discolouration of skin over nasolabial groove/ alae nasii.
    4.  Nasal crusting and nasal discharge which could be blackish or blood tinged.
    5.  Periorbital swelling/ Blurring of vision
    6.  Pulmonary involvement

# Diagnosis & Rx

*   Biopsy: aseptate hyphae with right angle branching & rhizoids present
*   Rx: Liposomal Amphotericin B in initial dose of 5mg/kg body weight (10 mg/kg body wt in case of CNS involvement) is the treatment of choice for 3-6 weeks following which step down to oral
    *   Posaconazole (300mg bd on day 1 f/b 300mg od) or Isavuconazole (200MG tid for 2 days f/b 200mg od) : step down therapy

# Candida

*   **Candida** occurs as part of the **normal human flora** and is found in the **GI tract** and on the **skin**.
*   **Invasive disease** may occur in the **immunocompromised**: **neutropenic patients**.
*   **non-specific CLINICAL & Radiological features**
    *   *Handwritten:* Hematogenous dissemination
*   Extrapulmonary manifestations of infection are common, e.g. **skin**, **eye**, **hepatic**, or **CNS** involvement.
*   Definitive Dx: (tissue invasion) by Candida on TBLB or surgical lung biopsy
*   âœ“ Rx: An **echinocandin** (**caspofungin**: loading dose **70 mg**, then **50 mg daily**; micafungin: 100 mg daily; anidulafungin: loading dose 200 mg, then 100 mg daily) is recommended as initial therapy â‰ˆ **2 weeks**
*   âœ“ Lipid formulation alternative [ AmpB ]
*   âœ“ **Fluconazole**, **800-mg** (12 mg/kg) loading dose, then **400 mg** (6 mg/kg) daily, is an alternative for patients who are not critically ill and have had no prior azole exposure
*   âœ“ Atleast **2 weeks Rx**

# KAPOSI SARCOMA

*   Kaposi sarcoma is the most common HIV-associated malignancy
*   Multicentric neoplasm consisting of multiple vascular nodules appearing in the skin, mucous membranes, and viscera.
*   The immune system damage caused by HIV allows cells harboring HHV-8 to multiply. Through unknown mechanisms, the characteristic lesions form.
*   Treatment : ART Antiretroviral therapy

Dr. Bharath kathi Pulmonologist

<!-- Page 186 -->



# LYMPHOMA
_mediastinal expan._
B-NHL

*   B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma is the most common HIV-associated lymphoma
    *   HIV Immuno suppression & co infection with EBV seem to drive B cell clonal expansion.
    *   CXR : include mediastinal lymphadenopathy, pleural masses or effusions.
*   better prognosis if patients treated with chemotherapy also receive ART.

# Multicentric Castleman's disease (Handwritten: AtleZumab)

*   MCD is a rare **lymphoproliferative** disorder characterized histologically as **angiofollicular** (Handwritten: \*\*) lymph node hyperplasia. ? Dysregulated **IL6**. (Handwritten: \*)
*   **Human herpes virus 8** & **Kaposi's sarcoma** associated
*   CF : cough and dyspnea
*   Radiology : reticular and/or nodular interstitial patterns, with **mediastinal lymphadenopathy** and less commonly, bilateral **pleural effusions**.
*   Dx : Biopsy
*   Rx : ART + anti-HHV8 therapy such as with **ganciclovir**
*   CD20 (rituximab) and Anti interleukin-6 receptor (**atlizumab**) (Handwritten: blotton) may be considered;



# PRIMARY EFFUSION LYMPHOMA

*   subtype of **NHL** that presents with **isolated effusions** in body cavities, including the **pleura pericardium**, and **peritoneum** 3P (Handwritten: \*)
*   presents with **lymphomatous effusions** in the absence of a discrete **nodal or extra nodal** mass.
*   Dx : Pleural fluid histology and identification of **HHV8** (Handwritten: \*) which can be found in all cases.Primary effusion lymphomas are of a **null phenotype**, lacking classic B-cell and T-cell markers.
*   Rx : **ART** and **systemic chemotherapy**.

(Handwritten: HHV8 -> Kaposi, castlmen, Pri eff lymp)

# Pul arterial HTN
Kranthi.krishna139@gmail.com
Group 1 HIV related Pul HTN
*   ? Unclear mechanism. HIV proteins may induce vascular remodelling
*   The optimal treatment of HIV-associated PAH is unclear.
*   Small studies have reported improved functional and hemodynamic parameters in patients with HIV and PAH during treatment with epoprostenol and bosentan.
*   Other treatments such as sildenafil and iloprost may also be useful.
    *   Prostaglandin (referring to sildenafil and iloprost)
    *   Limited evidence (referring to epoprostenol and bosentan)
    *   Endothelin receptor antagonist (referring to bosentan)

## SARCOIDOSIS
*   Although sarcoidosis would seem an unlikely disorder among patients with HIV, a number of cases of sarcoidosis or sarcoid-like disease have been reported
*   Have correlated the use of ART with the development of sarcoidosis.
*   Whether sarcoidosis in HIV represents a manifestation of IRIS is debated. ??
*   At presentation in majority HIV-infected patients with sarcoidosis had CD4. > 200 cells/ÂµL



## IRIS
IRIS describes a paradoxical worsening of clinical status related to recovery of the immune system following a period of immunosuppression.
(TB | HIV)

# Imaging
*   bronchopneumonia or lobar consolidation with cavitations
*   solitary, multiple or miliary nodules, and abscesses
